Environmental Issue/ Concern: TNew Pipeline in Alberta  rench subsidence
Location: 22010 - Approx. 90 sites in 110 km section between;  Section 2-31-4-W4 and  Section 34-22-4-W4.  011 – In addition to areas noted above, all land tracts were assessed in 2011
Current Status 2010: The total area within the 110 km section is approx. 1.8 ha. Typical areas are 20m in length, 2–3 m wide and <0.3m deep.
Current Status 2011: •  Numerous site deficiencies were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if very small or possibly in pasture/ native range, acceptable topsoil sources are secured and used to fill-in trench subsidence.  •  Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2012: •  Numerous areas (approx. 2500m or 1.4 ha) were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  •  Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2013: •  Numerous areas (approx. 3500 m or 2.5 ha) were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  •  Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Current Status 2014: •  Numerous areas (approx. 9100m or 9.1 ha) were corrected, using combinations of stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if acceptable topsoil sources could be secured, topsoil was used to fill-in minor trench subsidence.  •  Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: Continue with assessments in 2015, with remediation to be completed based on discussions with landowners; as well as potential to impact pipeline operations.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: UNew Pipeline in Alberta  nderground spring surfaced creating soft ground conditions around pipeline trench
Current Status 2010: Monitored in 2010 Also discussed during NEB Post-Construction Monitoring inspection in September 2010.
Current Status 2011: •  Monitored in 2011. Soft ground conditions did not correct naturally, potentially creating land-use (grazing) and pipeline operation issues. •  Implemented plan that included installation of gravel and weeping tile to divert flow away from the pipeline trench and onto stable, vegetated ground.
Current Status 2012: •  Monitored throughout 2012. Weeping tile appears to be working well, as soft ground conditions are no longer evident.  •  Vegetation is re-establishing well.
Current Status 2013: •  Monitored in 2013. Weeping tile working well, as ground conditions are good.  •  Vegetation is re-establishing well.
Current Status 2014: •  Monitored in 2014. Weeping tile working well, as ground conditions are good. •  Vegetation is re-establishing well.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: Area has been stable and drain has been working well over the past three seasons.  Issue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Trench subsidence and overall drainage around station
Location: NE 13-9-5-WPM Adjacent to Elm Creek Pigging Station (ECPS)
Current Status 2010: Unable to complete work in 2010 due to very wet conditions
Current Status 2011: •  Land-levelling completed around the ECPS in 2011. •  Ditch subsidence corrected/filled with land-levelling.
Current Status 2012: •  Monitored in 2012.  •  Drainage around ECPS appears to be OK.
Current Status 2013: •  Monitored in 2013. •  Drainage around ECPS appears to be acceptable.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: Drainage around the station has been working well over the past three seasons. Issue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Berm along drainage ditch adjacent to road
Current Status 2010: Work completed in July 2010 as part of Post-Construction Monitoring
Current Status 2011: •  Monitored in 2011- heavy spring runoff and summer rainfall, berm integrity maintained. Additional material was added to top of berm in 2011 during land-levelling of adjacent farm field.
Current Status 2012: •  Monitored in 2012 •  No issues with berm contours, elevation or integrity. Heavily vegetated.
Current Status 2013: •  Monitored in 2013. •  No issues with berm contours, elevation, or integrity. Well vegetated.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: No issues with the integrity of the berm or contours over the past three seasons. Issue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Drainage adjacent to MLV Carman 49+200
Current Status 2010: Work completed in November 2010 as part of Post-Construction Monitoring
Current Status 2011: •  Due to landowner crop loss claim in regard to ineffective drainage around compound, additional land-levelling completed Fall 2011. •  Fine-tuned drainage around compound.
Current Status 2012: •  Monitored in 2012.  •  Drainage around the MLV appears to be OK.
Current Status 2013: •  Monitored in 2013.  •  Fall of 2013 additional land-leveling to fine-tune drainage around valve compound.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: Continue to monitor in 2015.  Communicate with the landowner to ensure field drainage continues to work appropriately.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba Drainage within adjacent sections.
Current Status 2013: •  Monitored in 2013.  •  Fall of 2013 land-leveling in SE 11-2-5WPM to correct surface contours, restore 2 field drains, and restore elevation to a RM of Stanley trail. •  Fall 2013 land-leveling in NE 11-2-5WPM to recapture /restore topsoil washouts and to restore elevation at windrow of trees.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Manitoba  Potential land levelling
Location: Areas on numerous tracts. Sizes ranging from 5 m length to 200 m length, and 5 m wide to full width of right-of-way.
Current Status 2010: 2010 helicopter reconnaissance with video capability, some ground recon, as well as discussions with landowners noted inconsistencies in contours across the right-of-way. Land levelling completed in a few locations in 2010.
Current Status 2011: •  Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2011.  •  2011 assessments determined uneven field surface contours (high spots/low spots).  •  Normal farm practices do not readily correct these inconsistencies.
Current Status 2012: •  Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2012.
Current Status 2013: •  Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2013.
Current Status 2014: Land-levelling completed on 29 various land-tracts in 2014. All areas on the New Pipeline in Manitoba segment completed in 2014.

Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: INo further issues with vegetation establishment at this location. ssue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: NNew Pipeline in Alberta  ative Vegetation establishment
Current Status 2010: 2010 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Other than deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2011: •  2011 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.  •  Deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, indicates good native species germination and ground cover.
Current Status 2012: •  2012 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2013: •  2013 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2014: 2014 PCEM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Site Contours
Current Status 2010: Banks are stable in 2010, some minor slumping to be further assessed to determine if re-work and stabilizing bank is warranted
Current Status 2011: •  Banks remain stable in 2011.  •  Repair of minor slumping does not appear to be warranted at this time.
Current Status 2012: •  Banks remain stable in 2012.  •  Repair of minor slumping does not appear to be warranted at this time.
Current Status 2013: •  Banks remain stable in 2013.  •  Repair of minor slumping is not warranted as bank wraps are stabilized. •  Posts used for supporting the coir bank wraps were removed.
Current Status 2014: •  Banks remain stable in 2014.  •  Repair of minor slumping is not warranted as bank wraps are stabilized.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: INo further issues with bank stability at this location. ssue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Site Contours
Current Status 2012: •  Landowner communicated concern with final contours in three locations. •  Conducted assessment and determined that minor corrections are required to better blend/ fit to contours on right-of-way boundary.
Current Status 2013: •  One location was repaired in 2013. Discussion was had with new land owner and figured it was a non-issue.
Current Status 2014: Assessments in 2014 indicated no issues and there were no concerns mentioned by the new landowner.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: INo further issues with contours at this location. ssue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Shrub Planting
Current Status 2011: •  Planted approximately 170 Manitoba Maple and Chokecherry on banks, completed in June 2011.
Current Status 2012: •  Assessed area and determined that success was not adequate due to utilizing potted stock that was not mature enough for the site conditions. •  Larger/ more mature potted stock (115 plants) was planted in June 2012 and monitored throughout the growing season, with much better success to date.
Current Status 2013: •  Larger/ more mature potted stock (75 willow, maple and chokecherry plants) were planted in June 2013. •  Assessed area and determined that success appears to be adequate at this time. •  Livestock continue to have some affect when electric fencing is breached.
Current Status 2014: •  3 shrubs on the north side and 6 shrubs on the south side appear to be surviving from the planting in June 2013. •  Livestock continue to have some affect when electric fencing is breached.

Environmental Issue/ Concern: Manitoba  New pipe  Post-Construction Erosion concern
Current Status 2012: •  Landowner expressed concern regarding wind erosion and subsequent crop loss into a location that was land levelled by Keystone •  Although loss was indirect, as vegetative debris from an adjacent field created the conditions for soil erosion to take place on the Keystone right-of-way, the landowner was compensated for replanting and associated land management.
Current Status 2013: •  N/A as issue addressed in 2012.  •  Complete.
Recommendations/ Schedule for 2015: IFollow-up monitoring not required. ssue is deemed to be resolved and PCEM is considered to be complete.
